It all depends on the type of programming you’re doing and your operating system. Any laptop should at least have these features: Wireless internet2 or more USB portsPort for external monitorIn general, for Windows 10, you’re going to want more hard disk space and RAM. Windows 10, it’s a resource hog, but it’s widely used. For Linux, you can get by with less, especially if you carefully select the components you install. I won’t get into all the different Linux distributions; that’s not really my wheelhouse. If you want Linux, do your homework. Most of my advice will be from the Windows side of things, since that’s where most of my experience is. C/C++/C#: On Windows, you’ll probably want Visual Studio 2017 or later. Since it’s free, you really can’t go wrong with this fantastic IDE, but it does take a lot of resources. Get a laptop with a generous amount of RAM and hard disk space.Java: Takes a little less resources than the above languages if you use something like Eclipse. It will feel like it’s using a lot of resources because it runs so slow, but it actually takes a wee bit less. Your requirements will be a bit less compared to C++/C#, but not much. Get a hefty dose of both.Python/JavaScript: Doesn’t matter. These languages take so few resources that almost any computer will do. The thing that will bite you with Python, at least, is the IDE. Like most languages, you don’t really need an IDE, but the people who don’t use one are a called “masochists”. I like PyCharm for Python, which uses a healthy dose of resources. Is there even an IDE for JavaScript? You can use a nice text editor and your browser of choice (which should be Chrome) as your debugger. Least resources of the above languages.Sorry I can’t offer a specific brand and model number, but these change so frequently that by the time I recommended one, it would be discontinued and this answer would be stale. When I buy a laptop for programming, I get the absolute most computer I can afford. Max out on the RAM and hard disk space (but get an SSD if you can afford it). You don’t really need the latest CPU; almost any late-model CPU is fine (but buy Intel, because I have stock in Intel). At some point you’ll probably want to hook up your laptop to a real keyboard, mouse and monitor, hence the USB ports and external monitor hookup. Tip: the more USB ports, the better. TL/DR: Get the absolute most computer you can afford. Give priority to RAM and hard disk space; you need a CPU, but not a super-duper one.
